May 12, 2013: Fiction
THE HIT, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) The government hitman Will
Robie uncovers a serious threat as he attempts to take out a fellow assassin who
has gone rogue.
WHISKEY BEACH, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $27.95.) A former criminal attorney
who has been acquitted of his wife’s murder retreats to his family home on a New
England cliff.
FLY AWAY, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) A woman must deal with her
personal issues before she can keep her promise to help the family of her deceased
friend.
PARIS, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Doubleday, $32.50.) Characters real and imaginary
in the City of Light.
LIFE AFTER LIFE, by Kate Atkinson. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) A woman appears in
different versions of the same events, centered on World War II.
WEDDING NIGHT, by Sophie Kinsella. (Dial, $26.) A woman tries to break up her
sister’s impulsive marriage.
DADDY'S GONE A HUNTING, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.99.)
Two sisters are threatened by a dark secret from their family's past.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown, $25.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
THE BURGESS BOYS, by Elizabeth Strout. (Random House, $26.) Two brothers,
both lawyers, come together in a small Maine town to defend their troubled nephew.
THE MYSTERY WOMAN, by Amanda Quick. (Putnam, $26.95.) The second book of
a new Victorian paranormal series, Ladies of Lantern Street, by Jayne Ann Krentz,
writing pseudonymously.
DON'T GO, by Lisa Scottoline. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) An Army doctor returns from
Afghanistan when his wife dies in what at first appears to be an accident, and finds
that his life is falling apart.
THE INTERESTINGS, by Meg Wolitzer. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Six friends meet in the
1970s at a summer arts camp, and pursue success, and one another, over
succeeding decades.
SIX YEARS, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $27.95.) Jake Fisher discovers that neither
the woman he loved nor their life together were what they seemed.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) Book 5 of "A
Song of Ice and Fire."
Non-Fiction
LET'S EXPLORE DIABETES WITH OWLS, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $27.)
Essays from the humorist on subjects like French dentistry and a North Carolina
Costco.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf, $24.95.) The chief
operating officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without
ambivalence.
COOKED, by Michael Pollan. (Penguin Press, $27.95.) The writer masters recipes
and argues that regaining control of cooking will make Americans healthier.
TRIDENT K9 WARRIORS, by Mike Ritland with Gary Brozek. (St. Martin's,
$25.99.) The dogs that serve elite combat units.
DIRTY WARS, by Jeremy Scahill. (Nation Books, $29.99.) America’s new covert
wars, fought by secret commandos.
CARRIE AND ME, by Carol Burnett. (Simon & Schuster, $24.99.) The comedian
recalls her oldest daughter, who died in 2002.
MY NEXT STEP, by Dave Liniger. (Hay House, $19.95.) A businessman fights
back from a staph infection that paralyzed him.
THE NEW DIGITAL AGE, by Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen. (Knopf, $26.95.) The
promise and peril of the continuing information and technology revolution.
THE WAY OF THE KNIFE, by Mark Mazzetti. (Penguin Press, $29.95.) The
Times’s national security correspondent describes how the lines betwween the
C.I.A. and the American military have been blurred.
GULP, by Mary Roach. (Norton, $26.95.) A science writer’s pilgrimage down the
digestive tract.
THE DUCK COMMANDER FAMILY, by Willie & Korie Robertson with Mark
Schlabach. (Howard Books, $23.99.) Behind the scenes at the A&E show “Duck
Dynasty.”
I'LL SEE YOU AGAIN, by Jackie Hance with Janice Kaplan. (Gallery Books, $26.)
The experience of a mother whose three daughters were killed when her sister-in-
law drove the wrong way down the Taconic Parkway.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
MOM & ME & MOM, by Maya Angelou. (Random House, $22.) The developing
reconciliation between the poet and her mother, who sent her to live with her
grandmother at age 3.
